video:video.video:title: Photographer Revisits Underwater Paradise
video:video.video:description: National Geographic photographer David Doubilet explores the glittering world hidden beneath the waves of Papua New Guinea’s Kimbe Bay. After shooting a photo assignment there 17 years ago, he was eager to return.

video:video.video:title: Confiscated Plants Get 2nd Life
video:video.video:description: October 7, 2013—U.S. Customs officials confiscate many smuggled plants at ports of entry, mostly orchids as well as cacti and succulents. Many of those plants get a second life at designated Plant Rescue Centers, like the U.S. Botanic Garden in Washington, D.C..

video:video.video:title: Hit the Slopes with World's First Skiers
video:video.video:description: Today we might think of skiing only as an alpine sport. But its fascinating origins lie in China's Altay Mountains, with an ancient people who used skiing to hunt big game in deep snow. Their descendents still practice the art.

video:video.video:title: The Weed That Won the West
video:video.video:description: Two photographers on assignment for National Geographic magazine drove for miles through the American West in search of photogenic tumbleweed. Along the way, they learned some wild facts about this invasive plant.

video:video.video:title: Antlion's Death Trap
video:video.video:description: Not the King of the Jungle—but for ants these creatures might as well be. What lurks in the soft blanket of sand?

video:video.video:title: Black Mamba vs. Animal Kingdom
video:video.video:description: It's not a drink or a dance. It's only the black mamba, Africa's longest and the world's fastest snake. Oh, and one of the most poisonous too.

video:video.video:title: Albatross vs. Tiger Shark
video:video.video:description: Young albatrosses learn that a hungry tiger shark is an excellent motivator when learning to fly.

video:video.video:title: Anaconda Breeding Ball
video:video.video:description: Invitations are out for the breeding ball, but unless you're a male anaconda, you wouldn't want to be invited to this dance!

video:video.video:title: Cane Toads
video:video.video:description: The unwelcome and unstoppable cane toad is wreaking havoc on Australia's ecosystems.

video:video.video:title: Bull Sharks
video:video.video:description: Bull sharks are known man-eaters. Crittercam® goes with them to see how they hunt.

video:video.video:title: Baboons vs. Flamingos
video:video.video:description: Hungry baboons in Kenya's Lake Bogoria find themselves surrounded by a million unsuspecting—and unprotected—flamingos.

video:video.video:title: Ant and Butterfly Symbiosis
video:video.video:description: Why would ants and a butterfly caterpillar possibly need each other? Possibly for something sweet?

video:video.video:title: Burying Beetles
video:video.video:description: You want zombies? A scary movie? These beetles have most Hollywood horror films beat!

video:video.video:title: Bear River Romp, McNeil River
video:video.video:description: This clip from McNeil River State Game Sanctuary shows footage from the field by Elizabeth Wasserman of the National Park Service. Two sub-adult bears practice their fighting skills, all in good fun of course, in McNeil River.

video:video.video:title: Beavers Are Geniuses
video:video.video:description: In the Rocky Mountains, beavers build ponds, passageways, and warm winter homes.

video:video.video:title: Bluebirds
video:video.video:description: One man's dedication—and a very simple solution—have helped bring bluebirds back from the edge of extinction.

video:video.video:title: Baby Cobra's First Hunt
video:video.video:description: Everyone's got to learn sometime, even a baby cobra programmed for the hunt.

video:video.video:title: Anaconda Birth
video:video.video:description: Unlike the majority of snake species, anacondas give birth to live babies—sometimes 40 at a time!

video:video.video:title: Boomslang vs. Chameleon
video:video.video:description: A boomslang is one of the most toxic snakes in Africa, and a chameleon's camouflage is no match.

video:video.video:title: Bee vs. Jumping Spider
video:video.video:description: When you say jump, this spider says, "How far?" Some jumping spiders can spring up to 50 times their body length, leaping on prey, like this unfortunate bee, seemingly from out of nowhere.

video:video.video:title: Anaconda Bites Man
video:video.video:description: Memo to herpetologists in the field: When bitten on the hand by an anaconda, do not, repeat, do not pull away.

video:video.video:title: Centipede vs. Snake
video:video.video:description: Are this black-headed snake's eyes bigger than its stomach? Unfortunately for the centipede the answer is no.

video:video.video:title: Cobra vs. Monitor Lizard
video:video.video:description: Think you can guess who wins the day when two aggressive predators compete for the same prey?

video:video.video:title: Crab Chow
video:video.video:description: Who could possibly find a meal in beach sand? These sandbubbler crabs can and do when the high tide ebbs.

video:video.video:title: Assassin Bug vs. Bats
video:video.video:description: Think there's nothing scarier than a vampire bat? How about the bug that sucks its blood?

video:video.video:title: Apes With Tools
video:video.video:description: New photographs from researchers in Nouabale-Ndoki National park in Congo reveal that gorillas use tools, the first documented among wild gorillas.

video:video.video:title: American Crocodiles
video:video.video:description: Can't tell your crocs from your 'gators? National Geographic will show you how.

video:video.video:title: Polar Bear Mom & Cubs
video:video.video:description: When they're not playing, polar bear cubs learn under the watchful eye of their mother.

video:video.video:title: Boy Croc Meets Girl Croc
video:video.video:description: With snout-rubbing and bubble-blowing, two amorous saltwater crocodiles get cuddly.

video:video.video:title: Blue Whales
video:video.video:description: Blue whales have complex calls that can be heard for miles. One scientist is on a mission to uncover the meanings of their songs.

video:video.video:title: Anaconda Hunts
video:video.video:description: When you're an anaconda, you don't need venom to take down your prey, even if it's the world's largest rodent, a capybara, weighing nearly 100 pounds (45 kilograms)!

video:video.video:title: Bottlenose Males Are Mean
video:video.video:description: Docile dolphins? Not hardly. Sometimes these bottlenose dolphins seem to be just looking for a fight!

video:video.video:title: Animal Winter Games: Tusk Wrestling
video:video.video:description: Heavyweight walruses fight to be the last tusker on the ice.

video:video.video:title: Animal Mothers: Elephant Seal Birth
video:video.video:description: An elephant seal in the south Indian Ocean finds out that giving birth to a seal pup is no day at the beach.

video:video.video:title: Animal Mothers: Cheetah vs. Gemsbok
video:video.video:description: Two cheetah cubs think they've found an easy meal when they catch a gemsbok calf, until they are confronted by the calf's protective mother.

video:video.video:title: Bottlenose Hunt on Sandy Shore
video:video.video:description: Call it a bait-and-"swish" tactic. These bottlenose dolphins really know how to fish!

video:video.video:title: Bugling Elks
video:video.video:description: At Colorado's Rocky Mountain National Park, people flock to hear the call of the elks.

video:video.video:title: Animal Mothers: Newborn Gators
video:video.video:description: Watch how this protective alligator mother uses her "Jaws of Love" to protect her newborns from the dangers that lurk in the Florida Everglades.

video:video.video:title: Caribbean Cleaners
video:video.video:description: For some, a hungry clean-up crew is the best partner a fish can have.

video:video.video:title: Ameloctopus
video:video.video:description: One of the smallest octopuses in the world, an ameloctopus can lose arm after arm to predators and still live to fight another day!

video:video.video:title: Carrier Crab
video:video.video:description: A carrier crab uses a sea urchin's spines for a shield from predators.

video:video.video:title: Bears in the Berries, McNeil River, Alaska
video:video.video:description: This clip from McNeil River State Game Sanctuary shows footage from the field by Elizabeth Wasserman of the National Park Service. Here we watch as a mother rolls around in a field with her cub and then two older bears do the same.

video:video.video:title: Brave Bear
video:video.video:description: Watch a young polar bear vying for a piece of an older bear's meal.

video:video.video:title: Bat Hospital Saving Orphans
video:video.video:description: January 23, 2009—Australia's Tolga Bat Hospital is saving spectacled flying foxes orphaned by an insect-spread disease that is killing bat mothers.

video:video.video:title: Amazing Antlers
video:video.video:description: The male caribou grows antlers every year, and then throws them away!

video:video.video:title: Baby Chimp
video:video.video:description: Some primates are vegetarian, but not these chimpanzees in Tanzania. You wouldn't want to be a nearby Colobus monkey.

video:video.video:title: Black Flying Foxes
video:video.video:description: Australia's black flying foxes are big bats, with a wingspan up to six feet (two meters)!

video:video.video:title: Boat Alarm Could Save Manatees
video:video.video:description: June 4, 2009—Manatees can't hear the low sounds of boat engines, which is why the animals are frequently injured, a researcher says. A high-pitched alarm could solve the problem.

video:video.video:title: Arctic Hare
video:video.video:description: Watch some arctic hares run and frolic on the tundra of the north.

video:video.video:title: Bonobo: The Female Alpha
video:video.video:description: In bonobo society, it's the females that rule the world.

video:video.video:title: Arizona Condors
video:video.video:description: The endangered California condor has a new, out-of-state home: the Vermilion Cliffs of Arizona.

video:video.video:title: Animal Mothers: Walrus Cuddle
video:video.video:description: A walrus mother holds her baby like a human would! Separated from their herd, a walrus mother bonds with her newborn in the first few uncertain days of its life.

video:video.video:title: Bison Headbutting
video:video.video:description: Prepare yourself for the battle of the bulls in Yellowstone, when male bison battle head to head for a chance to mate with females.

video:video.video:title: Bowhead Whale
video:video.video:description: Now here's a question: How can a creature like the bowhead whale, which has no teeth, get to be 60 feet long and weigh up to 60 tons? Find out!

video:video.video:title: Angel Bees vs. Robber Bees
video:video.video:description: There are more than just honeybees and bumblebees in the world. And some even have to defend their turf!

video:video.video:title: Bed Bugs
video:video.video:description: An army of bed bugs can attack a person 500 times in one night! Sleep tight.

video:video.video:title: Croc's Breakfast
video:video.video:description: When you're a Nile crocodile, you have lots of breakfast options.

video:video.video:title: Bluefin Tuna Eat Bait Ball
video:video.video:description: A giant school of mackerel mass together for protection as they are picked off by tuna and dolphins.

video:video.video:title: Birds and Crocs
video:video.video:description: Some birds depend on a tiny African lake for food and water. But they must look out for the crocodiles that lie in wait.

video:video.video:title: Canada Goose
video:video.video:description: Canada geese take to the skies along their annual migration paths.

video:video.video:title: Bobcats of Kiawah Island
video:video.video:description: A bobcat is a predator, but rarely bothers humans. Some people on Kiawah Island, South Carolina, would like to see more of them.

video:video.video:title: Born to Run
video:video.video:description: Baby zebras must develop their racing legs if they're to survive until adulthood.

video:video.video:title: Biggest Trout Fished in Asia
video:video.video:description: November 13, 2007—Fishing the world's largest trout, Mongolia's taimen, is encouraged—to help save it.

video:video.video:title: Animal-to-Human Disease Watch
video:video.video:description: December 12, 2008—In remote corners, a research team is monitoring contact between humans and wild animals—particularly wild animal meat—in hopes of stopping pandemics before they start.

video:video.video:title: Anteater
video:video.video:description: Watch an anteater dine on termites, rooting out larvae with its 16-inch (41-centimeter) tongue.

video:video.video:title: Black-Footed Ferrets
video:video.video:description: They're cute and cuddly, but nearly went extinct. Follow scientists in South Dakota as they capture black-footed ferrets to help save them.

video:video.video:title: Animal Mothers: Wood Duck Paratroopers
video:video.video:description: Just one day after being born, wood duck hatchlings must take a frightening leap of faith to reach their mother.

video:video.video:title: Bear Scenes from Enders Island, McNeil River
video:video.video:description: This clip from McNeil River State Game Sanctuary shows footage from the field by Elizabeth Wasserman of the National Park Service. Here we see scenes from an active brown bear fishing area where brown bears bring their cubs to feed in the summer.

video:video.video:title: Black Rhino
video:video.video:description: A black rhino arrives at a wildlife conservation center to help give its species a much needed boost.

video:video.video:title: Cardinal
video:video.video:description: The mascot for many sports teams, this bird wears red at home and on the road.

video:video.video:title: Bat-Eared Foxes
video:video.video:description: Large ears help this tiny fox find its next meal. What will it be this time—lizard, scorpion, or some tasty bug?

video:video.video:title: Animal Winter Games: Race to the Ice
video:video.video:description: Emperor penguins try to make it past a lurking leopard seal on their way home to their chicks.

video:video.video:title: Bullfrogs Eat Everything
video:video.video:description: A bullfrog will go after anything it can fit in its mouth, even its own kind!

video:video.video:title: Anolis Lizard Love
video:video.video:description: It's not about muscles or money. No, it's all about an impressive throat sac when you're a male anolis lizard trying to attract a mate.

video:video.video:title: Bat Falcon
video:video.video:description: A bat falcon makes dazzling mid-air catches over Mayan ruins in Guatemala.

video:video.video:title: Cichlid Fish Mouth Fighting
video:video.video:description: Male cichlids size each other up then smack each other down—all based on the size of their mouths!

video:video.video:title: Crittercam®: Bear Cub
video:video.video:description: Bear's Eye View: Watch what happens when a three-year-old brown bear cub gets fitted with a National Geographic Crittercam®.

video:video.video:title: Chao Phraya Catfish
video:video.video:description: The chao phraya catfish, also known as the dog-eating catfish, can grow up to 9 feet long. This species is now extremely rare in the wild and in urgent need of study to assess its conservation status.

video:video.video:title: Chimps Use Tools to Hunt Mammals
video:video.video:description: February 22, 2007—See newly observed footage of tool-making behavior that further blurs the line between humans and chimpanzees, our closest living relatives.

video:video.video:title: Clownfish and Sea Anemone Partnership
video:video.video:description: Clownfish have evolved an ingenious though slimy way to use stinging anemones for their own protection.

video:video.video:title: Centipede vs. Grasshopper Mouse
video:video.video:description: The venomous mandibles of a centipede are no match for the lightning-fast reflexes of the grasshopper mouse.

video:video.video:title: Cobra vs. Rat Snake
video:video.video:description: A rat snake may look like it's related to this king cobra, but the cobra prefers to think of the rat snake as lunch!

video:video.video:title: Cheetah vs. Gazelle
video:video.video:description: An unlucky young Thomson's gazelle becomes fodder for a cheetah cub training for the hunt.

video:video.video:title: Clouded Leopard Breeding
video:video.video:description: Zoos in North America and Thailand may be the only hope of survival for the clouded leopard.

video:video.video:title: Cobra Mating and Birth
video:video.video:description: Even big, bad cobras need love sometimes.

video:video.video:title: Civets Love Organic Smells
video:video.video:description: With their sense of scent, you might call civets the perfume purveyors of the natural world.

video:video.video:title: Cockroaches Are Everywhere
video:video.video:description: With 4,000 species the world over, there's no avoiding roaches!

video:video.video:title: Coral Reef Spawning
video:video.video:description: A tropical setting in the Caribbean is where sperm and eggs meet to form these coral reefs.

video:video.video:title: Chimps and Tools
video:video.video:description: They haven't produced a computer yet, but chimapanzees are pretty good toolmakers. The big secret? Females chimps are better with tools than males!

video:video.video:title: Chimps Hunting in Trees
video:video.video:description: Many primates are vegetarian, but not these chimpanzees in Tanzania, as a group of colobus monkeys finds out.

video:video.video:title: Chameleon Babies
video:video.video:description: Home alone? That's how it always is for Africa's flapneck chameleons. Once she's created a burrow for her eggs, a female flapneck hits the road again, never to return.

video:video.video:title: Chimps Batter Hives for Honey
video:video.video:description: March 2, 2009—Pounding fortified beehives with big sticks and other tools, a chimpanzee group in Africa works hard for the honey (apologies to Donna Summer)—the most sophisticated honey-gathering methods seen in wild chimps.

video:video.video:title: Clams: Not Just for Chowder
video:video.video:description: They have no brain, but clams burrow deep in the mud to avoid predators such as the cow-nosed ray.

video:video.video:title: Druids of Lamar
video:video.video:description: Wolves are back in Yellowstone National Park, but they're not always welcome.

video:video.video:title: Dingo vs. Kangaroo
video:video.video:description: A dingo eyes a young kangaroo, and the hunt is on.

video:video.video:title: Octopus Squirts Bird
video:video.video:description: The cyanea octopus seems to like its solitary life, and will use its unique ink power to keep it that way!

video:video.video:title: Dipper Bird
video:video.video:description: Meet a bird that can "fly" underwater.

video:video.video:title: Deadly Mates: Black Widow Spiders
video:video.video:description: If you think the dating world of humans is tough, check out the love life of black widows, where one misstep can lead to a lethal end.

video:video.video:title: Diamondback Caterpillar
video:video.video:description: As both a caterpillar and a moth, the diamondback can do major damage to a field of crops. But researchers have found an ingenious way to stop them.

video:video.video:title: Octopus Changes Color and Hunts
video:video.video:description: Ever wish you could change shape and color the way the cyanea octopus can?
